title: Cross Site Scripting In Profile Statement

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
Hey Sir, I Have found Cross Site Scripting(XSS) Vulnerabilities in updating profile statement,
This is Advance XSS Script, You can see it XSS-Gratipay.txt
You can also see it live here:
https://gratipay.com/~MuhaddiMu/

Steps to produce:
1) Login To Your Account.
2) Click on Edit Statement
3) Copy and Paste the script I provided to you. 'F113916'
4) Save Statement & see it again.

See Screenshots I uploaded.
'F113918'
'F113919'


User Agent: Chrome and some others
Patching: Use Advance XSS Security

Thanks!
Regards: Muhammad Muhaddis (Cyber Security Researcher)

activities.message: Hi @muhaddimu, Thanks for your report. After taking a look at your screenshot, it seems that the stripped-down PoC is `![a](data:text/html;base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K)` (creating ``) but it's not working on my 3 test browsers. In which one (name/version) did you took your screenshot? Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @muhaddimu,

Thanks for your report. After taking a look at your screenshot, it seems that the stripped-down PoC is ![a](data:text/html;base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K) (creating <img src="data:………">) but it's not working on my 3 test browsers. In which one (name/version) did you took your screenshot?

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!

activities.message: Everything is correctly escaped in most of the cases: the only thing which is allowed is putting arbitrary data into the `src` attribute of one `img` tag. In addition, your screenshot shows the result of `alert('XSS')`, which seems to be the result of this line: `````` That's why I guess that I understand what's happening during the conversion from Markdown to HTML. The only point I'm missing are the name and versions of browsers which are interpreting this value while rendering this `img`. I've reached the daily limit of the website I'm using to test this kind of behaviours on a wide range of browsers—I'll be able to confirm it or not tomorrow. Thanks for your patience :-)
activities.markdown_message:
Everything is correctly escaped in most of the cases: the only thing which is allowed is putting arbitrary data into the src attribute of one img tag. In addition, your screenshot shows the result of alert('XSS'), which seems to be the result of this line:

<img src="data:text/html;base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K" alt="a">

That's why I guess that I understand what's happening during the conversion from Markdown to HTML. The only point I'm missing are the name and versions of browsers which are interpreting this value while rendering this img. I've reached the daily limit of the website I'm using to test this kind of behaviours on a wide range of browsers—I'll be able to confirm it or not tomorrow. Thanks for your patience :-)

activities.message:
OK, that's what I thought after your last message. In fact, this does not present any security implication since the context where the javascript is interpreted in is not the one of Gratipay: you can't access the cookies of the user, make XHR requests while impersonating him (same-origin policy)… since you're in the context of the new tab, which is `data:……`. 

You can try it by yourself by using the following payload to see the current domain:

`PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCh3aW5kb3cubG9jYXRpb24uaG9zdG5hbWUpPC9zY3JpcHQ+Cg==`

or the cookies of the user:

`PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydChkb2N1bWVudC5jb29raWUpPC9zY3JpcHQ+Cg==`

Both will be empty.

I'll see tomorrow if some browsers are directly interpreting what's inside the `src` attribute without requiring any user interaction. If not, I'll have to close this report as "Informative".
activities.markdown_message:
OK, that's what I thought after your last message. In fact, this does not present any security implication since the context where the javascript is interpreted in is not the one of Gratipay: you can't access the cookies of the user, make XHR requests while impersonating him (same-origin policy)… since you're in the context of the new tab, which is data:…….

You can try it by yourself by using the following payload to see the current domain:

PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCh3aW5kb3cubG9jYXRpb24uaG9zdG5hbWUpPC9zY3JpcHQ+Cg==

or the cookies of the user:

PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydChkb2N1bWVudC5jb29raWUpPC9zY3JpcHQ+Cg==

Both will be empty.

I'll see tomorrow if some browsers are directly interpreting what's inside the src attribute without requiring any user interaction. If not, I'll have to close this report as "Informative".

activities.message:
The result of Browsershots can be found [here](http://browsershots.org/https://gratipay.com/~nashe/#). I was not able to find any browser interpreting this value and displaying the alert in the context of Gratipay. 

Since it requires heavy user interaction even if he's using one old browser and the script is not executed in the context of gratipay.com, I'm closing this report as "Informative". If you ever find a way to bypass this limitation, don't hesitate to open another report!

Thank you for taking time to report your finding, I hope you'll continue to participate in our program in the future :-)
activities.markdown_message:
The result of Browsershots can be found here. I was not able to find any browser interpreting this value and displaying the alert in the context of Gratipay.

Since it requires heavy user interaction even if he's using one old browser and the script is not executed in the context of gratipay.com, I'm closing this report as "Informative". If you ever find a way to bypass this limitation, don't hesitate to open another report!

Thank you for taking time to report your finding, I hope you'll continue to participate in our program in the future :-)

summaries.content:
The researcher @muhaddimu found that during the conversion of `![img](src)` to HTML by [misaka](http://misaka.61924.nl/), the `src` field of the generated `img` tag is not sanitized. It allows the usage of sources like `data:text/html;base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K`. While we were not able to find  any browser interpreting this attribute while rendering the page (no alert windows is shown), it can be only triggered by doing a right click on the element and then choosing "Open in a new tab". By doing so, the browser interprets the javascript code in another context than gratipay.com—it's impossible to get user's cookies (in addition of the `HttpOnly` flag) or to make any XHR request to gratipay.com. 

Since we can't find any direct security implication of this behaviour, this issue was not considered to be a security risk.
summaries.content_html:
The researcher @muhaddimu found that during the conversion of ![img](src) to HTML by misaka, the src field of the generated img tag is not sanitized. It allows the usage of sources like data:text/html;base64,PHNjcmlwdD5hbGVydCgnWFNTJyk8L3NjcmlwdD4K. While we were not able to find any browser interpreting this attribute while rendering the page (no alert windows is shown), it can be only triggered by doing a right click on the element and then choosing "Open in a new tab". By doing so, the browser interprets the javascript code in another context than gratipay.com—it's impossible to get user's cookies (in addition of the HttpOnly flag) or to make any XHR request to gratipay.com.

Since we can't find any direct security implication of this behaviour, this issue was not considered to be a security risk.
